mtSusie 0.1.1

    • Multi-trait SuSiE with interaction terms

    Multi-trait SuSiE with interaction terms

    Yongjin Park

    mtSusieInter.Rmd

    A toy example

    Let’s generate a toy example to illustrate the problem.

    set.seed(1331)

.rnorm <- function(d1, d2) matrix(rnorm(d1*d2), d1, d2)

n <- 200                                  # sample size
p <- 1000                                 # number of predictors/variants
m <- 10                                   # traits/outcomes
h2 <- .2                                  # heritability/proportion of variance exampled by X
X <- .rnorm(n, p)                         # this can be replaced with a real genotype matrix

K <- 3                                    # random conditions
W <- (sign(.rnorm(n, K)) + 1)/2           # 

causal <- sample(p, K)

y <- .rnorm(n, m) * 0

for(k in 1:K){
    wx <- W[,k, drop = F] * X[, causal[k], drop=F] 
    y <- y + wx %*% .rnorm(1, m)
}

Y <- apply(y, 2, scale) * sqrt(h2) + .rnorm(n, m) * sqrt(1 - h2)
    library(mtSusie)
mt.susie.1 <- mt_susie(X, Y, L=4, prior.var = .01)
    ## Fitting mtSusie ...
    ## Done
    mt.susie.2 <- mt_susie(X, Y, L=1, W, prior.var = .01)
    ## Fitting mtSusie ...
    ## Use 2 levels per each interaction term
    ## Done
    susie.result <- NULL
for(l in 1:ncol(Y)){
    susie.l <- susieR::susie(X, Y[,l], scaled_prior_variance = 1e-2)
    susie.result <- rbind(susie.result, data.frame(variants = 1:ncol(X), traits = l, pip = susie.l$pip))
}
susie.result <- data.table::as.data.table(susie.result)

    Take credible sets with or without interaction effects.

    cs.1 <- data.table::setDT(mt.susie.1$cs)[order(lbf, decreasing = T), head(.SD, 1), by = .(variants, traits)]
cs.2 <- data.table::setDT(mt.susie.2$cs)[order(lbf, decreasing = T), head(.SD, 1), by = .(variants, traits)]

    For the causal variants:

    susie.result[variants %in% causal][order(1-pip, variants, traits)]

    For the non-causal, false discoveries:

    susie.result[!(variants %in% causal) & pip > .05][order(1-pip, variants, traits)]
    ##    variants traits        pip
## 1:      439      9 0.37500969
## 2:      830      9 0.37096207
## 3:      271      4 0.13226398
## 4:      505      4 0.08214124

## 6:       76      4 0.06060457
## 7:       85      4 0.05596346
## 8:      867      4 0.05213056
## 9:      207      4 0.05077836

    We may improve power. For the causal variants:

    cs.1[order(lbf, decreasing = T)][alpha > .05][order(traits)][, .(variants, traits, alpha, z, lfsr)][variants %in% causal]
    ##     variants traits     alpha           z         lfsr
##  1:      598      1 0.9999999  5.17563915 5.662441e-06

    Including interaction effects, we can improve the interpretability in parsing out credible set results.

    cs.2[order(lbf, decreasing = T)][alpha > .05][order(interaction, traits)][, .(variants, traits, interaction, alpha, z, lfsr)][variants %in% causal]
    ##     variants traits interaction alpha          z         lfsr
##  1:      598      1           1     1  5.8859410 4.470348e-06
##  2:      598      3           1     1  4.3046722 6.127357e-04
##  3:      598      4           1     1 -0.4126123 3.758285e-01
##  4:      598      5           1     1  7.3247275 0.000000e+00
